key_points: Colonial Pipeline has resumed normal operations following a ransomware cyberattack, delivering millions of gallons of fuel each hour.
The pipeline now services all its markets including states from Texas to New Jersey.
Despite the resumption, there are widespread fuel shortages with up to 80% of stations in Washington D.C. without fuel.
The cyberattack forced the shutdown of about 5,500 miles of pipeline, leading to widespread shortages and panic buying.
Colonial carries almost half of the fuel supply for the East Coast, including gasoline, diesel, and jet fuel.
Operations restarted on Wednesday evening, but not immediately at full capacity.
Colonial paid nearly $5 million in ransom to the cybercriminals, as reported by an anonymous U.S. official.
The cyberattack was coordinated by a group known as DarkSide.
The Department of Energy led the federal response, in coordination with the FBI, Homeland Security, and the Department of Defense.
Colonial committed to investing in resources to maintain safe and reliable operations.
